author: ralexstokes
content: yeah so you still can do no better than honest majority for one chain vs another

author: ralexstokes
content: but w/ in a single chain, you can get a proof from the last accepted block root thru the state root to the latest finalized checkpoint so that a light client can know (with just a reasonably sized proof) that a given block was finalized or not by the broader validator set (as seen by the current sync committee the light client is following)

author: ralexstokes
content: i was thinking about this attack the other day and i believe that if a malicious sync committee did try to fork, they would have to wait a long time thru the finality leak before they could finalized a conflicting chain (wrt the "main" chain)

author: ralexstokes
content: so the light client would need to be eclipsed for quite some time and we could also imagine heuristics in place such that the operator at least gets some warnings if it falls into this situation

author: zsfelfoldi
content: I guess the client could also check a few randomly selected shard committees and do more checks if they're not all on the same chain.

author: zsfelfoldi
content: If i understand correctly, in the 'SyncCommittee' container (that is hashed into the beacon chain) there are 1024 bls pubkeys listed which makes sense but then there are 16 aggregates of 64 keys each. Where is this useful? Do you expect that validator participation will be so high that there's a reasonable chance that every key in a 64 group does indeed sign so it's cheaper to prove the key aggregate of the signing set?
